div.head: ACT ONE

stage.stage: Breakfast-room at the Brauer residence . The back wall is formed by three glass doors , separated by marble pillars . Behind this , the veranda is visible , and balustrade , hung with fine rug , and stairs , leading into the garden . The glass doors have practical , solid wooden shutters , with bars , fastening inside . Doors R. and L. Large table C. with breakfast laid . Front , to the left , sofa , table and easy-chair . To the right , sewing-machine , and basket filled with table-linen . Old-fashioned photos and engravings on walls . Otherwise , well-to-do family home .

div.stage: Gertrude busy at breakfast-table .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Enters with Paul , from R .Confound it ! Everything seems to go wrong this morning !

div.stage: Throws his cap on chair , angrily .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Happily .Good-morning , papa !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Morning , my child . Such carelessness ! You ought to be ashamed of yourself . If this thing had happened earlier in the season , out on the meadows — but at this time of the year —!!! Oh ! Confound it all , anyway !!!!! It is inexcusable !! !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: What is the matter , papa ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: The black cow has been overfed . But of course , when Marie is not about to look after everything , things go to rack and ruin . Well , man , what excuse are you going to make ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: None , Mr. Brauer .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Now that 's the most sensible thing you have said this morning . Here , take a cigar and get to work ; but mind ! send for the veterinary surgeon at once . Have you had breakfast ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Yes , sir !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Then what the devil are you waiting for ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: I — I — I wanted to excuse myself , and ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Impatiently .It 's all right ! it 's all right !

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Remains — hesitatingly .G — Good-morning ! !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: I — I have something else to tell you ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Then out with it .

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: With a glance at Gertrude .But ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: H 'm ! Gertrude , darling , will you please see if it is still threatening rain ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , papa !Goes out on the veranda .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Confidentially .The old hag has turned up again .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Alarmed .Wha —— The devil you say ! H 'm ! Who — who has seen her ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: She was seen begging in the village — and last night , one of my men observed her creeping stealthily around the sheds yonder .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Scratching his head .Yes , yes ! I had almost forgotten . She has served her last sentence — fully five years !— we have been free from her annoying presence and now , she has returned . Well , what does she want ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: She has heard her daughter is about to be married , she says .

lg.l: Her daughter ? ha , ha ! I see ! no doubt she has learned of
Gertrude 's betrothal . Well ? and ——

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: And so she has come to get her share of the wedding-cake — so she says ; but she dare not venture here .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , I should advise her to keep a respectful distance . Take good care , Mr. Paul , that she approaches no one of this house . Do you hear ? No one . I will see the constable myself ; and perhaps we 'll soon get rid of her again . Good-morning .

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Good-morning , Mr. Brauer .Exit .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Enters .Shall I pour your coffee , papa ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: What ? My little one looking after the breakfast , eh ? Can you do all that ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh papa ! if I could n't do even that ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But Marie ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh , of course — not as well as she — you must have patience with me , papa !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Why certainly , my pet !Embraces her .And now , let me see — how many days are you left to me ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Only four more days , papa .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Now , you rascal ! must you leave me ? must you go and marry , eh ? must you ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: But papa , dear , it is all your own arrangement !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Of course , of course ! what is a poor old man to do ? Have you seen George this morning ?Gertrude shakes her head .Such sloth ! He does nothing but sleep , sleep , sleep .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: He worked until very late last night , papa . At dawn this morning I saw his light still burning ; and then it was past three o'clock .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Yes , I must admit , he is diligent and industrious — but also stubborn — damned stubborn .The last is said almost to himself . Aloud .Has mama been down ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: No , not yet .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And Marie ? has she returned ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: She arrived by the early morning train .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And how nearly finished is the lover 's nest , eh ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Only one more trip to the city , I believe she said .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , and do you like the arrangement ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: I do n't know , papa dear . I am kept entirely in the dark . It is to be a surprise to me . Oh , I will like it very much indeed , I think .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And are you happy , my pet ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh , papa , dear , I sometimes feel as if I did n't deserve all this happiness .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , my dear , a housewife who calls these soft-boiled eggs , certainly does not deserve such happiness .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Embarrassed .I only boiled them about three-quarters of an hour ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ha , ha , ha , ha !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon , papa , I will ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: There , there , I was only joking ; never mind it . And Marie , I suppose , is taking her rest now ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: If she only would do so . Papa , you must compel her to take a rest . No one can endure such a strain . One day she is looking after this house , and the next day she is in the city , furnishing our new home ; and the nights she passes on the train . I am sure she will break down .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , well , I will look after that .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Enters from L .Good-morning !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Morning ! Well ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Throws her arms around her mother .Good-morning , mama dear !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Caressing her .My sweet ! my pet ! only four more good-mornings , and then ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: You must come to visit me soon , mama !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Crying .Visit ? ah , yes !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: No tears now , no tears , I beg of you ! Tears on an empty stomach — b-r-r-r-r-r , that 's poison .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: My darling , who dressed your hair last night ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: The housekeeper .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: There ! I knew Marie could not have done that . But do you know — Marie — a few moments ago I opened her door softly , to see how she was resting , and found her still fully dressed , just as she came from the train , seated at the open window , a book in her lap , and staring out into space .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , well , well ! I thought her passion for novels had passed away long ago .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: I 've been thinking — we must watch her more closely .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: She needs no one to watch over her ! She is well able to take care of herself ; but we must spare her ——

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: But , Henry , just now — three days before the wedding — who could think of sparing one 's self ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , you know — h 'm ——

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Henry , you know how I love the girl ; but , good gracious , she is not our own dear , sweet one ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh , she is more than that , mama dear .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: You are entirely too modest , my darling .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Well , just imagine , mama dear , she was going to be married — and I remained at home ——

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Then we would retain our sunshine , our consolation , our ——Looking at breakfast table with a questioning expression .But , children , I can n't understand ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: What , mama dear ?

lg.l: Gracious ! Everything is so — so —
If she is not going to sleep , she may as well come down here ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Laughingly caressing her mama .There , you see , mama , dear , not even a single meal can you eat without her .

div.stage: George von Harten enters .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , at last you have aroused yourself ; you ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Interrupts him , tapping his hand .There , softly , softly , dear uncle ; do n't begin scolding so early in the morning .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Do n't you think it 's pretty near time to call me father , my boy ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Not until after the wedding , dear uncle .— Good-morning , auntie .

div.stage: Kissing her hand . ] Well , little one ? [ Kissing her .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Leans on him lovingly .My George .Laughs suddenly .Oh , just look ! he is simply covered with hay !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Then you may make yourself useful by brushing me off .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: The hayloft seems to be your favorite sleeping-place lately .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Sleep ? Heavens ! who could sleep in this weather ? I roam about . Lord knows where , over meadows and fields . Such St. John days !!! It 's enough to drive one mad . The days never seem to end . Late last night I was sitting in front of my window . Said I to myself : “ No sleep for me to-night , until that cursed nightingale runs out of melody ” — when suddenly a meadow-lark announces the break of day — and there , it 's morning . To the left , the twilight : to the right , the dawn , peacefully together . From glow to glow a new day arises . Children , I tell you , it was beautiful . Give me a cup of coffee .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But , tell me ! Are you going to remain here now ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Why , certainly , until after the wedding .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But the propriety of such a thing ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Imploringly .Oh , papa dear ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Its immaterial to me . Under no circumstances do I desire to offend your sense of propriety ; but then I will stay down at the inn , as the nearest place .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And in the morning you will bring us the house full of fleas .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: But , Henry ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , it 's so .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: If you will allow me ! The wedding was set for the twentieth ; therefore I obtained my first furlough from the nineteenth — and I trust you realize that I can n't change the dates to suit myself . I arrived on the twentieth — and the wedding , of course — it was postponed .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: But , George dear , neither your home , nor anything else was ready .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And besides , where am I to go ? My own home is broken up ; Marie has had everything torn up . By the way , has she returned ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Why , what 's the matter ? Have you two had another quarrel ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: No , certainly not ; but I should not have allowed the girl to make a drudge of herself for my sake . I almost wish I had remained at home .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Why , she is not doing all this for your sake , but for mine .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Now there , do n't be conceited .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Caressing her .I think she has cause to be conceited .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: As my future wife , she certainly has cause to be that .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: There , there , do n't you overrate yourself .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I do n't , dear uncle ; I am too practical for that .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: So , so , you are too practical , eh ? then what the devil possessed you to leave this piece of paper on my desk ? eh ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle , I beg of you , do n't let us begin quarreling so early in the day .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Angry still .Very well , but what does it mean ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: It is simply a statement of my affairs . I am a free and independent man , and that is to show you that I am not only willing but also able to properly support my wife .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Still worked up .But I tell you ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Enters R .Oh — pardon me , papa — good-morning !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Throws arms around her .Marie !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Kisses her .My darling !

div.stage: She goes to Brauer and kisses his hand .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: You are back all right , I see ! Here , here !Puts hand under her chin .Head thrown back , I say — why , what 's the matter ? anything gone wrong with you , eh ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Uncertain .N — no !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: To his wife .Look at her — she is positively livid .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: What is the matter , my child ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Mama , dear , I sat up all night in the train and have had no sleep at all .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And how much longer will it take you ——?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Only one more trip to town ,— but pardon me , papa , the new assistant pastor is at the gate and ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: The new assistant pastor .

div.stage: Gertrude snickers .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: To Gertrude .What are you laughing at ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Pulling at Marie 's skirt and can hardly keep from bursting out laughing .I — I — oh , I am not laughing .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: To Marie .But what does he want ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: He says he does not wish to disturb the ladies so early in the morning , and asks you to please come out ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Nonsense ! tell him to come in .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , papa .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Good-morning , Marie .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Good-morning , George .Exit .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Gertrude , come here . Now remember , my dear , such conduct is not at all becoming to a full-grown young lady .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: My dear , sweet papa , I am so ashamed of myself — I — I 'll never do it again — never . But it 's so funny — ha , ha , ha ! he is gone on Marie ——

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: My dear , remember you are now a bride and it would be far more proper to say ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Smitten with her ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Somewhat reproachfully .George !! !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Sh , sh — silence !

div.stage: During following scene , Marie noiselessly clears off the table .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Enters .I should not have dared to annoy the ladies at this early hour , if ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Laughingly .Eight o'clock is not so very early in the country , my dear Pastor ; you will soon learn that here .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: And how is the good old pastor ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Doubtfully shrugging his shoulders .Well !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Alarmed .He is not worse , I hope ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: At the age of eighty , my dear lady , one cannot be said to be growing stronger .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ah , I see , Pastor , you are somewhat of a philosopher . Will you take something ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: You are very kind . A good glass of brandy is half the morning sun .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Now that is a manly word , Pastor .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Oh ! thank you ! Your health !Drinks .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Will you take something , George ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: No thank you , uncle , not now .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: When did you arrive , Pastor ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Just three weeks ago .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: And do you like our town ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Very much indeed , thank you . I find the whole world beautiful ; but the surroundings here are exceptionally so . Yes , this place to me seems doubly attractive , for here every one seems smiling and happy —— Pardon me . Miss , you have dropped the napkin .

div.stage: Marie smilingly bows her acknowledgment .
Gertrude exits , stifling a laugh .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Pastor , you will pardon this rudeness , she is still a child .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Oh , certainly , certainly ; for she is right . I have not yet been able to overcome my old tendency to play the gallant in the presence of ladies — and in this frock — I know — I must look somewhat ridiculous .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Tell me . Pastor , how did you happen to obtain this position ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Well , you see , that , too , is partly connected with this coat . There were four of us , classmates — who , after graduating , were eagerly awaiting the call to save the sinful world — and among them , myself the only one who was , what you might say , in fairly good financial circumstances . We were now and then compelled , first one and then the other , to present ourselves at the board of directors — and as a consequence my coat suffered severely . Now it really never fitted any one of my comrades and at my suggestion we finally purchased a coat , that came nearer fitting each of us , striking a happy medium , as it were , to every one 's satisfaction . Then , about four weeks ago , an ex-fellow-student — the curate of the cathedral — came to us , with this information : “ Ye holy men , list ye to me . In yon Lithuanian mountains lives a minister of the gospel , who , on account of his extreme age and feebleness , is incapacitated from properly performing his duties . And as there are four of you , I propose that you draw straws and leave it to chance who shall be the favored one . ” At that the others unanimously declared : “ No , he who has shared with us his clothing shall be the favored one ” — and — well , here I am and , I fear , not half as pious as I look .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ah , courage , Pastor , courage ——

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Pray do not think that I am ashamed of my calling ; believe me , like our Lord and Master , my heart aches for suffering humanity , and therefore it has ever been my desire to follow in His footsteps . Besides , it was my father 's wish . You must know my father is a well-to-do farmer — there are no really large estates in the lowlands — but he has considerable — yes , I might say , a great deal of money — and owing to my early surroundings , I 'm afraid I am much better suited for a farmer than a minister of the gospel . But I will not give up , and continue to struggle and rid myself of all my bad habits . Your health !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Do you know , Pastor , I am beginning to like you ! Do you wish to remain here and take the old pastor 's place ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: I really would like ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Very well , my vote you shall have !

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: You are very kind , indeed . With such a position I should be quite content , and to complete my happiness —— but , by-the-bye , the object of my visit was , really , the bridal-sermon . I am afraid our good old pastor will not be able now ——

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Ah ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Simultaneously .Will not be equal to the exertion , you mean ; ah — I feared as much .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Therefore , if you will allow me — unless you desired some one else ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Pastor , if we had not already heard you in the pulpit I would deny your request , point blank , as you are practically a stranger to us . But your ways and sentiments please me , and therefore — what say you , wife ?She nods .— And you , George ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know ; but unless I am very much mistaken , there is already a great deal of sympathy between us , eh , Pastor ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Now I must confess that is rather meaningless , at least so far as I am concerned ; for my sympathy extends towards the whole world .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: At any rate I am glad ——

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Jestingly .Then will you kindly leave us for awhile ? I desire to inquire into your past record .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Shakes his finger laughingly .With pleasure , if you promise not to be too severe on me .Exit .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Now , then , with your kind permission , I will take a few notes ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Certainly , Pastor !

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: This young gentleman , your nephew , is especially close to the family , is he not ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Correct !

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Pardon me , but may I ask in what way ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: I will tell you . Pastor . It was in the year ‘ 67 , when we had here in East Prussia , a terrible drought — a year of distress and — do you remember anything about it ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Very little , as I was then still quite young .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ah , it was terrible ! Potatoes and fodder rotted before ripening . Of wheat and rye hardly a trace . We farmers , I tell you —! Then it was , when my brother-in-law , the husband of my sainted sister , whose estates were in the neighboring township yonder , realized one day his financial ruin and with all his aristocratic pride — you understand — he saw no other way — he resorted to the pistol — he committed suicide .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: And the — your sister , still lives ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Thank God , no ! but from that day ——

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Pardon the interruption ; but I have heard your daughter , Miss Marie , called “ the calamity child ” by some of the villagers . Has that any connection with this year of distress ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: And you did n't know that , Pastor — how she came into our house ? Well , during that same terrible winter , we were returning one night , my husband and myself , from the town , where we had at our own expense erected a soup-kitchen — when suddenly , at the corner of the woods yonder , where the road makes a sharp turn , our horses shied — and there , in the middle of the road , we saw lying , a woman , with a child pressed closely to her bosom . She refused to stir and begged us to put her out of her misery . Of course , we took her into the sleigh at once — ah , she was in an awful condition ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: I tell you , Pastor , it was months before we could rid the blankets of vermin .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: And the child , the poor little thing ——! But after being bathed and fed , and lying there , between the clean white covers , we both stood over its bed — the little thing , with its pinched face , laughed at us and stretched out its tiny hands — my husband said to me : “ Wife , I believe this is our share of all this sorrow and misery that heaven has sent us . ”

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: For you must know . Pastor , that our own daughter , Gertrude was then not yet born .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: No , not until three years later . Well , we bought the child from that miserable , drunken woman , in proper , legal form — determined and glad to get rid of her , for she did smell so of gin , I could not endure it any longer .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: That is what the worst drunkards in these parts prefer to brandy .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Unfortunately !! !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But to come back to my nephew ——

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Pardon me , another question . What became of the mother ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ah , that is a bad story — and just to-day ——

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Yes ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Oh — nothing , nothing . Anyway — that woman really did return , and as we did not want the child to see her , we gave her more money . Of course she remembered that and so finally she became a positive plague .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Oh , Henry , I have often thought since , perhaps a mother 's heart prompted her ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: You think so , eh ? Then perhaps a mother 's heart also prompted her to steal at the same time ! for every time she honored us with a visit , something or other disappeared , until I grew suspicious , had her watched , she was caught red-handed — and , of course , a long term in prison was the result .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: And the girl — does she know or suspect anything at all ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: We told her , her mother was dead . But one day she really did see her .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: How did that misfortune happen ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: It was on her confirmation day , just as the girls left the church in a body , when we heard a cry . What had happened ? Why , that woman had been lying in wait for the procession ; when suddenly she appeared , seized her child , and kneeling before her in the road , passionately covered her hands and feet with kisses .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Shuddering .Horrible !!!!! !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: I tore the child from her arms , of course , and carried her into the house . We had to make some kind of an explanation ; a drunken vagabond , I told her ! Did she believe it ?— H 'm ?— Then she fell ill ——

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: And how is it now ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Humorously .Why , Pastor , you seem very much interested .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Enters . Gertrude follows him in .I presume I am pretty well done by this time .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: We have n't even started with your case . The pastor is interested in something of far greater importance .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: With meaning and moved .You must not believe that , Mr. von Harten ; but there are lives whose fates are surrounded by so much mystery ——with a glance at Marie , who enters L. with package of linen .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Who follows his glance .Yes , yes , you are right .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: If you will allow me , I will call again about the sermon .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Giving him her hand .Pastor , you know you are always welcome in this house .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Give my regards to our good old pastor . Towards evening we will see him , as usual .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Oh , I had almost forgotten ! He desires me to ask you kindly , should you again favor him with eggnog , to please add a little more sugar , for the last was a trifle tart .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Why , of course , the poor old soul .

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Do not say that , madame ; for when the time has come when all our wishes and hopes and desires are concentrated upon a small quantity of sweets , our sufferings are near the end . And now , adieu . Miss Marie , adieu .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Preoccupied .Adieu .

div.stage: Pastor exits , accompanied by Brauer .
Gertrude enters .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Do n't be afraid dear , no one will scold you .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh mama , I 'm so ashamed of myself . When he arrived he seemed so jolly — and now — I am sure he is offended .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: He was not offended , dear , only a little grave .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: At any rate , what do you think of him , Marie ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Glancing up from her work , sorting linen .Of whom , mama dear ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Why , the new pastor .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh mama , my mind is so occupied , I had n't given him a thought .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Aside to George .Now you tell her , George .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Gertrude , how about our manzanillo-tree — any blossoms this morning ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: You do n't mean to say you have n't looked after that beloved tree of yours this morning ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I have had no time , mama dear .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: To George .Now tell her .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , both Gertrude and myself insist , that you cease this endless drudgery for our sakes ; it is n't right .

div.stage: Marie , humming , pays no heed — looks into space .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: See , she is not even listening .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: What 's that you are singing ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I —? Was I singing ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Well then , humming .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh yes , last night at the station I heard a strange song — some one in a fourth-class coach was singing . Listen .Sings .“ Zwirio czenay , zwirio tenay — kam'mano bernyczo — Rid wid wil dai dai — Ne'r mano bernyczo . ”

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And the Lithuanian text — you memorized it just from hearing it ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Well , where did you learn all that ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Why , I have always known it .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And could you translate it readily ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh , it means nothing , really —makes one or two attempts .— “ here ” — no ! “ I look here and I look there — where may be my lover ? Rid wid will dai dai — Nowhere is my lover ! ”

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Enters during this , unseen by her , puts arms around her . She shrieks .There , there —caressing her .Patience , my darling , some day you will have one — perhaps very soon . Why , what 's the matter , dear ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Leans on him in tearless sobbing .Oh , you have frightened me so !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: What is the matter with you this morning ? What has happened ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I have already told you , nothing .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Tut , tut ! something has gone wrong ! I can see it — and now , I demand that you tell me the truth .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Well , then — yes !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: What is it ? Come , come , out with it .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Some one attacked me .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Attacked you ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Not far from here .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: As you came from the station ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , I never — but everyone around here knows you and your character ; how did he look ? was it a vagabond ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Hesitatingly .N — No . It was — a gentleman ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Did he lay hands on you , or even try to touch you ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But you say he attacked you ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Attacked me — yes !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: You mean he followed you ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: How far ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: As far as the gate , which I opened quickly and then he disappeared .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: To the others .Now , what do you say to that ?George shrugs his shoulders .There is something queer about it all .To Marie .And that is what upset you so ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh , I am already much composed .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Raises her head .Yes — you look it .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh , papa , do n't torment her so .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Now , then , go and take a good nap .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Not yet , papa dear , I can n't . I must speak with George first . About the large bookcase — I really do n't know where to place it .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But you can do that later , can n't you ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I fear I might forget it .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Very well ; I am going down to look after the cow . Will you come , wife ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Rising and putting up her handwork .Yes , dear .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: To Marie .And one thing more ,— do n't you put your foot outside of the gate without an escort hereafter ! Understand ? Not once !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: But why not , papa dear ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: After what has happened ? But I never heard of such a thing — never , as long as I ——

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: But , Henry , in broad daylight , it is hardly necessary ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: No matter ; I have my reasons for that ; besides — well , I 'll tell you later .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: In passing taps Marie on cheek .Now , pet , go and take a good rest .Both exit .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: You must go , too , Gertrude !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Peevishly .But why should I ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: You know , dear , your future home ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Ah , yes ; those stupid furnishings ! Do you know , I do n't think a wedding half so much fun as Christmas . Now do n't be long , will you ?Exit .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Why so deep in thought , suddenly ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I —? Oh , I was thinking . I was picturing to myself that cosy little nook , your corner room !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , dear , how can I ever thank you for all the ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Do n't speak of it , George , for I take great delight in having the furniture moved about ; and then , I say to myself : “ Here is where they will take their tea , and there they will while away their leisure hours ” — so —— But , what I meant to tell you ! Yesterday we had an accident — the large mirror in the parlor was broken . I know it portends ill ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: What care I , so long as our friendship will not be broken .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: But why should it ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: It shall never be my fault , Marie .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Certainly never mine . But what I wanted to say ,— I had the large mahogany bookcase repolished . Is that satisfactory ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Anything you choose to do is satisfactory to me .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Hesitatingly .And then — I must tell you , George , something important . When I unpacked the bookcase , I found a blue manuscript .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Unsuspecting .What kind of a manuscript ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: George , you must not leave that lying around — not even hidden behind the books , especially now , when you take your wife to your home .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: In heaven 's name , what manuscript ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I believe — it contains some poems ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: You believe — it contains some poems . I have missed it since early last winter ; I thought I had lost it . Marie , now tell me truthfully , have you read its contents ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: N — no !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Then why do you tell me not to leave it around ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Well , I read the first part , and had begun on the second , when I concluded to go no further .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And you really looked no further than the first ? Absolutely no further ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Can you swear to that ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I can !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Then swear !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I swear ! Are you satisfied ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes , thank heaven ! But you must not imagine for a moment that the book contains anything I am ashamed of ; on the contrary , I consider it so sacred I would not have it desecrated by a stranger 's eye . About four years ago , something occurred within me — within my soul . No one knows — no one could even guess , and no one shall ever know .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No one ? Not even I ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: No , not even you . But where is the book ? Give it to me !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Turns up stage and takes it from her bosom .Here it is .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: How shall I ever thank you ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I want you to do me one favor . Will you promise me ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: If it 's in my power , certainly !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Then I must first confess to you . A few moments ago , when papa questioned me , I deceived him . I was attacked last night — yes — but not by a man , but by a woman — a Lithuanian woman . George , that woman was my mother !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: But I understood your mother was dead .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No , no ; that is not so . Not one of you ever told me the truth . On the day of my confirmation I was waylaid by that very same woman — I cannot have been mistaken .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Come , tell me , how did it happen ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I was walking along quietly — ‘ twas already dawning — when suddenly a gaunt form arose from the ditch beside the road . I looked , and saw before me a miserable beggarwoman , who called out to me in a trembling voice : “ Marie — Madame — Daughter ! ” I turned cold in fear and horror , and , unable to utter one sound , I began to run ; and I ran , ran , ran , and behind me I only heard her agonizing call : “ My Marie — my daughter ! ” And so , I ran away from my own mother . And now , after a few hours ’ thought , I realize I did wrong . I must see her and speak to her , and learn from her own lips who and what I am ; and as papa has forbidden me to leave this house — I would go in spite of him , but I have a fear — I beg of you , George , dear , go to her , I implore you , find her for me — she cannot be far away , and ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And then ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Then bring her to me , into the garden , or , better still , into this room towards evening , when papa and mama are calling on the old pastor ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , I cannot do that !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: The first time I ask a favor of you — and you say you cannot do it ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , dear , listen to me ! You have been so kind to me of late — and that has not always been so ; but if you had sacrificed for me even more than your own comfort and rest , I — I could not do it — I could not deceive your father and mother , for I fear the consequences .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Then can n't you understand that , a foundling though I am , a desire might come over me to see my own mother , though she be but a common beggar and an outcast ? That I might want to lay my head on her shoulder and be petted and fondled , and cry myself to sleep on mine — on my own mother 's breast ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Are you not fondled , are you not petted — has mama not always been kind to you ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , but it is not the same — not the same . Never have I felt the desire , the demand within me for my own flesh and blood , as just now .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: But why just now ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Imploringly .Because my heart is bursting . Oh , George !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I cannot . I dare not do it !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Then you refuse me ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: You know I must ! !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Then have you forgotten what took place in there , in your heart , four years ago ?

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , you have read my manuscript !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , I read it . Will you do it now ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , you have sworn falsely !! !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Shrugging her shoulders .Will you do as I ask ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: ‘ Tis well ! I will do as you ask !!! !

div.stage: Curtain .
END OF THE FIRST ACT .

div.head: ACT TWO

stage.stage: The same scene as Act I .

div.stage: Marie , seated , with some linen in her lap , at the sewing-machine , looking dreamily out of the window .

lg.l: May I come in , Miss Marie ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh , is that you ? Yes , come in !

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: I see you are working on Miss Gertrude 's wedding outfit . How beautiful , fit for a princess . But what I wanted to ask you : Madame has given me the menu for the wedding feast , and as to fish , it calls for carp . Now you know I am economical , but carp — common carp ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Why , carp is a very fine fish ——

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: Oh yes , and good enough for — say — your wedding feast ; but not good enough for Miss Gertrude .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: For my wedding feast even carp is too good .

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: Oh no ; carp is not too good for you , though it may be good enough — and do you know I will prepare a special Polish sauce — but Miss Gertrude — she must have deep sea fish . Now will you see Madame about that , please ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Very well , I will speak to mama about it .

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: And you are not offended ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh no !

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: For , after all , you know , you are only a foundling .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh yes , I know .

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: But we all love you , Miss Marie , and ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Thank you . But have you seen Mr. von Harten this morning ?

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: No , I have not ! But I have some good news for you — the assistant pastor has fallen deeply in love with you .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: And he is going to ask for your hand !!! I always said you were a lucky girl . Just think , you may be a St. John'shYpppHeNbride .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: And what is a St. John'shYpppHeNbride ?

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: You do n't know that , Miss Marie ? Well , I 'll tell you . It is written in the new seal of Solomonis : “ Whoever shall give or receive their first kiss on St. John 's eve , their love is sealed and they will be faithful unto death . ” So it is written in the new seal of Solomonis .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Enter C ., hands behind her , with bouquet .Marie , I have something for you . No , first I want Katie to leave the room . Go now , go !! !

sp.speaker: Katie
sp.p: Oh , I am going — I am going !!!!!!!! !Exit .

lg.l: Shut your eyes now !
lg.stage: Marie does so , as Gertrude holds bouquet to Marie 's face .
lg.l: Now what is it ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: The tulip-tree ! the first blossoms from our manzanillo-tree ! It blooms — it blooms !! !Burying her face in the flowers .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Are you glad , Marie ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , darling , so glad !!! Thank you !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: And do you know who picked them ?— George !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: For me ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Why , of course , for you !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: He — did this — for me ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: He would do even more than that for me , I am sure !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh yes , certainly ! But where is he now ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: I do n't know !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Did he say he had to go somewhere ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , he had to go out on the fields , he said — and that was quite some time ago . I wanted to accompany him , I begged and begged , but he flatly refused to let me go .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Breathing heavily .Oh !!!!!!! !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: I do n't know how it is ; but to-day he is acting so strangely . Papa has asked for him several times — and do you know , dear , at times he is not at all pleasant to me !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: But why should he ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: That 's just it ! why should he ? Oh , if I only knew — if I was only certain he loved me — and then , another thing — I do n't know if I should tell you — I have a growing fear , some other girl will take him away from me .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: With forced laugh .Away from you , dear ? how could that be possible ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh yes , you may laugh ; but at times , when he looks at me , I see a strange look come in his eyes . Half affection — half pity — and I do n't want to be pitied ! Why should he ? Am I not happy ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Caressing her .Yes , dear ; you ought to be very , very happy .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: But I cannot rid myself of the fear , perhaps he really loves another and is only taking compassion on me ! Oh , if I only knew ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: But , my darling ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: For you see , I am still so young — and think , how ill-mannered I was only this morning ! I was so sorry afterwards — but I do love to laugh .Laughs .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: With strange y desperate tone of voice .And you shall laugh — laugh — laugh — so — so !!!!!! !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Mama , too , insists that my love for him is only that of a child and not of a woman and a bride ; but you see she would rather I 'd not marry at all and so remain at home with her all my life . But you will be good to her , wo n't you ? You will soon be her only one .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Why yes !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I shall soon know whose only one I am !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: What are you saying ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: As George enters .There he is !

div.stage: Gertrude runs towards him . Marie takes a few steps , then hesitates and stops .

lg.stage: Pulling him , as she runs towards him .
lg.l: Oh , George !! !
Confound you !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Reproachfully .Gertrude !!!!! !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Crushed .Why , what did I say ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Lovingly .Now listen to me , little one . Such language may be excusable in your papa , but never in my bride .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Pouting .Everything I say seems to displease you . You never find fault with Marie ! You can go and marry her !! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie does not want to marry me .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: My very best thanks , George !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: For what ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Picking up bouquet .For this !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Oh , do n't mention it .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Were you out in the fields ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , papa is angry with you , too . He is looking for you !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Oh yes — I know ——! Well ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: In what direction did you go ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I have been everywhere .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: And have you found ——?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: What was he to find ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes , what was I to find ? But , children , your tulip-tree is certainly a strange fellow . There he stands , blooming alone , like the last rose of summer ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: My great-grandfather brought it from South America !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: To Marie .And that is why you love it so , because it is so foreign and strange ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Busy with linen .Perhaps !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: No , that is not the reason ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Well then , what is it ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: I 'm going to tell on you . One day papa took her to the Opera , down in the city ; there they saw the African ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: “ L'Africaine , ” you mean ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , yes , that 's what she called it .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Gertrude , please do n't ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: In that play occurs a poison-tree — I think ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes , a manzanillo-tree !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , yes ; and whosoever inhales the odor of its blossoms must die . And do you know what she did ? Oh , yes , I did the same — we would go to this tree , smell of its blossoms , and lay down ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: To die ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: To die .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Now you can imagine , George , how long ago that must have been .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , it was long , long ago . But about four years ago , one day Marie really wanted to die very badly .

div.stage: Marie casts a frightened glance at George , who returns it thoughtfully .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: But we did n't .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: No , no , thank heaven . Now , little one , run along and tell papa that I am here .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Marie , will you come , too ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No ; I think I will remain here a little while longer .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Then I 'll stay , too .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Now , little one ——

div.stage: Gertrude exits with a sigh .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Quickly and suppressed .Did you find her ?George nods .Will she come ? Why do n't you answer ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , when you exacted this promise from me this morning , I did not realize what it meant . I had never seen your — I do n't want to speak that word — I had never seen this person until to-day . She must not come to this house , secretly — she must not !! !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: George !! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Take uncle into your confidence , at least .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No , no one — no one but you ! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: What do you want with her ? You know you belong to this house . Here you have everything your heart desires . Here you have love — here you have ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Interrupts him .Bread ! Why do n't you say it ? Yes , here I have bread !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I did not mean to say that .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No ; but I did ! And do I not earn it , as well as the little love I obtain in this house ? I am “ The Calamity Child ” — and I do not ask for charity .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: You seem to be possessed of the very devil to-day !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Perhaps !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I implore you , do not insist . I fear the consequence . You will see ! for whatever is done against nature , punishes itself .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: And is it against nature when a child cries out for its own mother ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: She is not your mother ; your mother is in this house .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Gertrude 's mother is in this house , not mine . A mother must feel for her child , she must see ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Sh — sh !

div.stage: Enter Gertrude .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: You two are continually talking in whispers ; can n't you tell me ? It makes me so unhappy !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Caressing her .But darling , it is all done for your sake !

div.stage: During this , George looks at her disapprovingly , while Marie casts a timid glance at him .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Enters .At last you have come . Where in thunder have you been all day ? It almost seemed to me as if you were trying to avoid me !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: But , uncle ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , girls , have you prepared the pastor 's eggnog ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oh , I had entirely forgotten it .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Then see to it at once . And do n't forget the sugar , you know .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , papa .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And Gertrude dear , you can go and help her . It is time you were learning to do something yourself .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , papa !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I hardly think it will be ready in time to take with you and mama .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Then bring it later — yourself .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: With a glance at George .Could not Gertrude bring it , papa ? I have so much work to do !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: No , no , papa !! !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Yes , yes , you shall !— bring it up when done ; and mind , you remain at the pastor 's as long as your mother and I , this time . Understand ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh , papa dear ! The last time , the old pastor insisted upon holding my hand in his so long ; and they are so cold and clammy , so shriveled and hairy , like the hands of the dead !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Come here , my child . Those hairy hands once christened you , and at your confirmation the same shriveled hands were laid upon your head and invoked for you the blessings of heaven ; and would you , after all that , refuse to hold them in your own warm young hands ? My daughter , I do not wish to hear that again .Kisses her .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Slowly has approached George . Softly , aside to him .You will do as I ask ?

lg.l: And now , leave us .
“ Now , then , comes your turn , ” says the stork to the worm .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Looking after the girls , turns .I suppose so , but take a care , uncle , I am not so easily digested .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: We shall see ! We shall see !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: What do you want with me ? My financial condition is satisfactory . I have a good position , and my future is assured . I desire to enjoy the results of my own labors , not those of yours .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: So , so !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes , dear uncle . If you were so determined upon giving a large dowry , you should have found another husband for Gertrude than myself .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Riled .Oh , hang you and your confounded pride !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes , I am proud ; and because of my pride and determination , and , I may say , defiance , I have become what I am !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Rather arrogantly .And was there no diligence ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: That , also , was nothing but defiance .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: I almost believe you are determined to create another rumpus , as you did twelve years ago .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: If necessary , yes !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And was it necessary , even then ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: You ask me that question ? When one day I came here , during vacation from college , you insisted upon my attending your church . I refused . You gave me my choice , either to do as you asked , or have my allowance cut off . Then I resolved in my mind never to comply with your command , in spite of everything . Oh , it is no pleasure to hunger , as I was forced to do then ; but you may believe me , as I stand before you now , a free and independent man , I owe all of it to my stubborn confidence in myself , looking neither to right nor left , but straight ahead , without concessions , without falsehoods , always able to look every man straight in the face . And this good conscience is my proudest possession . From it do I draw all my strength , and I will never give it up .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , who the devil asked you to give it up ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And one thing more . Of course , I belong to this house ; fate has made it my lot . Therefore it has ever been far from my mind to seek a wife elsewhere , so strongly attached do I feel myself to this house ; and that would have been impossible , had I not from that day been a free man . And now , dear uncle , you are at heart a good and kind man ; but your hand is heavy , and it must not lie upon me again as that of the master . For that reason do I refuse to touch even one penny of the dowry , now or any other time .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: So , so ! Then you are really afraid of me ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Afraid of you ? Bah !! !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And at heart you are nothing but a coward ! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle , I forbid you ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: You forbid me ? Ha ! This is my house , and here I am the master !

div.stage: George shrugs his shoulders .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Yes , yes ; it seems to annoy you to have any one keep an eye on you and your conduct ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: My life has been as an open book to this day .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But after to-day — what about that ? Who can look into the future ? Who can look into your heart and read your thoughts ? Who knows what may happen over night , eh ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle , these are insults I will not endure , even from you ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well ! What then ! Come on !Jumps up , facing him , ready to fight .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Enters , ready to go out , dressed .Henry , what on earth have you done to Gertrude ? She is in her room , crying as if her heart would break .

div.stage: Marie has also come in with Mrs. Brauer .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: How is the eggnog getting on , Marie ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: It is not quite done , papa !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Then let her have her cry ; she can bring it up later .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , papa .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: And are you ready ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ready for what ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Are you ready to go now ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , wait for me out on the veranda ; we have something to settle first , we two !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: What 's the matter with George ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Oh , I have just asked him for an explanation , and that does not seem to please him .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Caressing him .Do n't you mind him , George dear . After the wedding you can laugh at him .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well , we shall see about that !! !

div.stage: Mrs. Brauer and Marie exit .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: We can n't go on like this , for I fear the consequences ; but , nevertheless , I shall handle you without gloves .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: My child loves you . You are her ideal , her all , and the wedding must take place . But tell me , what right have you to all this pride — I might even say arrogance ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Must I perhaps ask your permission ——?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: That is the same old defiance , the same unreasonable stubbornness of your father 's !!!! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Starts .My father has been dead these twenty years — what do you want of him now ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: What do I want of him ? That he left you to me , to bring up from childhood , I will hardly mention ; although that ought to be sufficient to temper your untamable pride — at least towards me ; but ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle , you may abuse me as much as you please , but my father I will not have disturbed ! My father — you shall let him rest in peace !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And who was it — who took care — who made it possible , that he could rest in peace ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle , what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Well then , who was it , when he laid there , dead , before us , who paid his debts of honor and saved your father 's name from disgrace ?

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle , you should not have said that !

div.stage: Sinks in chair and covers his face with his hands .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: My boy ——Emotion stops him from saying more — walks about .See here ——Again the same — tries to light a cigar , breaks it and throws it away .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: You should not have said that , uncle ! No , no ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: My God , you knew of it ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes , I knew of it , and yet you should not have said it ; you should not have repeated it . Twelve years ago , in our quarrel , when you raised your whip to me — and I reached for the carving-knife — no , no — I should not have done that . You should not have raised your whip , nor I the knife . That is the reason I refused anything from you at all . Now you know it . From that day I swore to scratch the gold from the ground with my finger nails and fling it in your face . From that day I hated you — and rightly so !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And all that because I saved your and your father 's name from dishonor and disgrace ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: No ! But because you turned that same deed into a weapon to crush my youthful pride .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: My boy , one uses the weapon nearest to hand .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Bitterly .Even if it is only a whip . But then , I see my mistake . I have no right to pride ; my fatherly inheritance does not permit it . Give me your gold ! I 'll take it ! All — all !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: No , no ; in your present state of mind I will force nothing on you . You might again turn to hating me .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Ah no , dear uncle , that is past . Hereafter , I will swallow my pride .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: My boy ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Enters .Pardon me papa , but mama asks , if you are not yet ready to go ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: With a glance at George .Well , as far as I am concerned , I am ready now !Takes his hat .Marie , give him a glass of brandy to brace him up .Goes to door and returns .George ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle ?Brauer offers his hand .My hand I cannot refuse you .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Goes to door . In door .Yes , and your heart , too , I will win again — or I 'll be damned !!! !

div.stage: Exits , slamming door .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: What did he say to you , George ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Do not ask me , do not ask me !Walks about .All these years I have struggled and deprived myself with only one thing in view — to be free — free — and yet I must bow — I must bow . If it were not for the sake of this beautiful child , who is innocent of it all , I would be tempted to —— But the die is cast , the yoke is ready — and so am I !!!!!! !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Softly and hesitating .But , George , dear , here in this house , I see nothing for you but love — the yoke seems so light ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: How pious and tame you have suddenly become !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I am not pious .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: What was that you said a few moments ago ? “ I am the calamity child . I am the child of misery ; but I do not ask for charity . ” That is what you said of yourself , and it is also true of me . I , too , am a child of misery , a calamity child ; but I am a subject of charity . I accept all they have to give — all — all — ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: You , George , a calamity child ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes ! Was I not picked up from the street , as my uncle so kindly informed me for the second time — like yourself ? Do I not belong to this house , and am I not smothered with the damnable charity of my benefactors , like yourself ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I receive my share with thanks .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And you enjoy serving ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I enjoy serving ! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: But I — I wish to rule — to command !! !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: And you shall rule — you shall command ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Walking about and ironically .Ah yes !! !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Timidly .George ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: The same .Pardon me ; but have you forgotten —?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Oh , I see !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I know it is wrong in me to annoy you at this time , when you are so occupied with affairs of your own —— Besides , you have already refused me once ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Wha — yes , now in spite of them all , I am my own master . I am responsible to no one . I have promised you — I shall keep my word !!!! !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Thank you , George !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Oh , do n't thank me ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Where is she now ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: She is waiting , behind yonder garden hedge .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: My God ! Do not keep her waiting any longer ; call her in here .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Gertrude is still in the house .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I will get her out of the way . When I appear out there on the veranda , the coast is clear ! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , for your own sake , I warn you for the last time ; discovery means certain disaster .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: One disaster more or less , it matters little !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Is that your last word ? Very well , I will bring her to you .Gets his hat and goes out centre door .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Opens door L. and calls out .Gertrude ! Gertrude !

div.stage: A door is heard to open .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Outside with crying voice .What is it ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Come quickly , or papa will be angry !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: After a moment 's pause .I am coming !Another short pause and she appears in door .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: How red your eyes are ! You have been crying ! What 's the matter , dear ?Caressing her .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Where is George ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Lightly .He went out again a few moments ago .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: And he did n't ask to see me ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: He heard you were crying and did not want to disturb you .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: But , Marie , what is the matter with your own eyes ? And you look so queerly ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: My pet , they are the eyes that God has given me and ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Suspiciously .What ?

div.stage: A knock at door is heard .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Come in !

sp.speaker: Maid Servant
sp.p: Enters with basket .Here are the eggnog and cakes , for the pastor . Now be careful and do n't crush them !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Very well !

div.stage: Exit Servant .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Taking basket .Good-bye , Marie !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Good-bye , Gertie dear !

div.stage: Gertrude starts towards centre door .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Frightened .Where are you going ?

lg.l: I am going through the garden across the fields ; perhaps I will meet
George .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Concerned .No , no ; you must not walk across the fields alone . Papa has forbidden it .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: But I may meet George .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: But if you should n't , what then ? No , no , I will not allow it ! I will not ! I had such a fright last night .

lg.stage: Goes up to the other door and turns back once more .
lg.l: Marie , you are not angry with me ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Embracing her .My darling !! !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Then I will go that way !Looks all around .Give my love to George !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: But I wo n't see him , dear ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Well , perhaps you may !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: In that case , I will tell him ——

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Very well .

div.stage: Exit R .

Marie goes out on veranda — gives sign — returns — locks doors R. and L .— then at C. door — in terror , with searching eyes , she slowly retreats backwards , her eyes glued on the outer darkness — until she finally covers her face with her hands , and is standing against the wall .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Enters .Here she is ! !

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: Enters . George goes out on veranda , looking off .Mine lady , mine daughter — yes — do n't be afraid . Oh , you are such a fine lady — you have lover — you marry , they say ——?

lg.l: No ; I 'm not to be married ! It is
Gertrude , my foster sister .

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: You no marry , eh ? Never mind — you marry some day — some dayExamining Marie 's dress with her fingers .What a fine dress you have , and all wool ——Same with apron .Oh , and a silk apron — all silk ! Give me , give me ?

div.stage: Marie takes it off and gives it to her .

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: Thank you — thank you !! !Kisses Marie 's sleeve and dress , but when she would kiss her hand , Marie withdraws it quickly .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No , no ! Ne dosu ranka !

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: All right , all right ! You are fine lady .Looks about .Is the old man home , eh ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: No , he is out .

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: That is good , that is good ! He is an old devil — is the old man ! All Prussians are devils . But he have fine house , he have ! Like a prince !! !Rubs her hand over table cover .Ah , nice shawl that would make ——Sees linen .And what fine linen —Motions to Marie .Come here !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Approaching her .What do you want ?

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: Pointing with thumb .Give me an drink — just an little drink !Indicates with finger and thumb .

div.stage: While Marie turns to sideboard , she quickly takes two or three pieces of linen and with left hand holds them hidden under her apron .

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: After taking drink from Marie .Thanks , mine daughter , thanks !After drinking , rubs her stomach .Ah , that 's good , that 's good !— Give me another !Marie fills another glass for her — she drinks it .Thank you , thank you !! But now I must be going !

div.stage: In her anxiety to get out she drops one piece , while going to the door .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Horrified .Mo — mo — what were you trying to do ?

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: Pretending surprise .My , my — just see ! I found this out on the field .Picks it up and puts it under her arm .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Put that down , it is not yours .

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: Doing so .All right , all right — my — my — my ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Put down all you have !

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: I have no more , no , no more , I swear !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Goes quickly to door and calls .George !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Enters .Well ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Give me some money !He gives her a gold piece .Marie to her mother .Here , here is money ; now give me the linen ——

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: Takes the money as she gives up the linen , greedily .A ducat ! A whole ducat ! A golden ducat ! Mine daughter , thank you !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: And now , go !

sp.speaker: Gypsy
sp.p: Goes anxiously to the door .Alright , alright !! !

div.stage: Throws a kiss to Marie , and quick exit .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Quickly takes key from board .George , take this key and lock the garden gate after her , so she does not return .

div.stage: George exits . Marie looks after them , then slowly returns to the table , leans against same , and stares vacantly . Knock is heard at door L .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Mechanically .Come in !

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Trying the door from the outside .The door is locked !

div.stage: Marie opens the door .

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Enters with dishes .It is time to lay the table for supper — will you help me , please ? Why , what 's the matter ? You are not listening to me ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Never mind , Lena , I will set the table myself !

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Will you ? Very well !! !Exit Servant .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Enters . To Marie , who does not stir .Remember what I told you . But come , come , this will never do ! Do n't stare at me like that ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Leaning on him and weeping .Oh , George !

lg.l: That 's it , dear , the tears will relieve you ! Ah ,
I well know the anguish of an aching heart !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , you know , you know all ! Now I have no one in this whole world but you — you alone .As she bursts out crying she throws herself on his breast .

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Stroking her hair .Yes , yes ; we two understand each other . We two were meant , were intended for each other . Were we not , dear ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: My God ! Yes ! !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: And we will ever remember this day — the day that brought us together . It is the day before St. John 's Eve . Will you remember it , dear ?

div.stage: Short pause . Marie silent , then struggles to free herself .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Do n't , George ! Go away ! Please do n't !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Embarrassed .But why should I suddenly go away , Marie ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Go , George , I beg of you ! I must lay the table !! Now go !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Marie , you said yourself you had no one but me !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: If you do not want to despise me , please go ——

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: With forced laugh .I despise you ? Very well — I 'll go ——

div.stage: Turns once more in the door and hesitatingly exits .
Marie breaks down , weeping .
Curtain .
END OF THE SECOND ACT .

div.head: ACT THREE

sp.speaker: Same setting . Above the centre table a lighted hanging-lamp . Another
sp.p: lamp on table , L. The glass doors to garden are open . Full moonshine falls partly into the room . At rise of curtain , at table , L ., are Brauer , Mrs. Brauer and Pastor . At centre table , Gertrude and George . It is evening .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Now , then , tell Marie to bring the bowl !

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Ah ! you are going to have a bowl ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Why , of course , Pastor . This is St. John 's Eve . The villagers will set off tar-barrels and bonfires , and we will celebrate it with a bowl .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Mischievously .But perhaps this festival is too heathenish for the clergy ——

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Bless you , that all depends . If you have not the clergy 's sanction , then it is wicked and heathenish ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But if they are invited , then it is Christianly and good ? Ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Well , I did not say that . You had better apply to the consistory , they are better able to decide that point .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ah , Pastor , you are a diplomat . Well , what are you two doing over there ? You are not saying a word .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: George is too lazy . He is drawing little men , and I am writing .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: In his place I think I would prefer to draw little women . Eh , Pastor ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Just as you say , uncle !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Aside .What the devil is the matter with him to-day ? Come , children , be jolly , this is St. John 's Eve ! Ah , here is the punch ! Now , then , Gertrude , lend a hand !

div.stage: Marie has entered with the bowl and glasses .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Yes , papa .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Drinks .Excellent , Marie ! Superb ! I tell you , Pastor , whoever gets her for a wife will be a lucky man indeed .

lg.stage: With a glass to George , who has gone back and is looking out .
lg.l: Do n't you want some , George ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Caressing her , with a shy glance at Marie .Why , yes , little one , thank you ! Look , how bright and beautiful the moon shines to-night ! Everything wrapped as in silvery spider web ! How beautiful !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Oppressed .They will soon set off the bonfires .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: See , see — at last you have spoken ; I feared you had lost your tongue . Come here , my child . Get your glasses , all of you —— Your health ! The Pastor shall give us a toast ; yes , yes , Pastor !— a genuine pagan toast , well suited to this night ! Now , tell me , my child , are you obliged to go to the city again to-night ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , papa dear .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But if I will not allow it ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: You gave your permission quite two weeks ago , papa dear !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But not to go in the middle of the night !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I must go , papa . The men are to be there at seven in the morning , and if I am not there to give instructions the house will never be finished in time .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Never mind , Henry , there is no help for it .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But look at her !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Why , papa , there is nothing the matter with me . I am well and merry ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: You are merry , eh ? Let me hear you laugh !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Tries to laugh .Ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Imitating her .Yes , yes — ha , ha , ha ——!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Come here , my child .Strokes her hair .Did you sleep well last night ?

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , mama .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: But if this stranger should attack you again ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Pardon me , but what do I hear ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Oh , nothing of importance , Pastor .To Marie .You will take the one o'clock train ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , papa .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: There is another — at four — t'will be daylight then ——

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: But I would not reach the city in time .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Very well , you need n't go to bed , then . George can take you to the depot .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Startled .George ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Startled and simultaneously .What — I ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Certainly ! Why not ?

sp.speaker: Pastor
sp.p: Pray do not think me obtrusive ; but I am at your service .

lg.l: No , no , thank you . Pastor ; your time will come some other day .
It will at least give him something to do .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: I want to go too , papa ! I love moonshine promenades .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: No , no , my pet . In the first place , it is very improper for lovers to be out so late at night , without a chaperon .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: I would much prefer to go alone . I am not at all afraid — and I do not wish to trouble George — or any one else ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Any one else is out of the question , for in this house every one rises at five in the morning .To George .Now , then , what excuse have you to offer ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Excuse ? I ? Why , none at all , except that she does not want me to go . You heard it yourself !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Have you two been quarreling again ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Do n't insist , Henry , if they do n't want to ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: By the way , send for Mr. Paul — I wish to speak to him . Pastor , your health !Drinks .

div.stage: At this Marie and Gertrude go to door C ., and speak to some one outside in pantomime . A voice is heard .

sp.speaker: Voice
sp.p: Mr. Paul ! Mr. Paul !

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: From behind scene .I am coming in one moment !Short pause . He enters .Here I am !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Ah , there you are ! Give him a glass of punch !

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Thank you , I have just had a glass of beer .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Very well ! Now , do n't let us disturb you , children ! Pastor , this is the time to prepare your toast .Aside to Paul .Well , have you learned anything of this stranger ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Not a sign of one , excepting two tramps at the inn , the gendarme placed under arrest ; but that was the day before yesterday .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: H 'm ! If I had ever had the slightest reason to doubt her word —— Marie , my child , come here to me .

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , papa !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Looks at her sharply .Never mind , now .

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Aside to Brauer .By the way , I saw the old woman again !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Sh ! not so loud ! Where ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: She had money , too ——

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: I wonder where she stole it ?

lg.l: I wonder ! The innkeeper said she had a gold piece . But do n't you worry ,
Mr. Brauer . She will soon give us cause to have her locked up again .
She is incorrigible !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: Does she sleep at the inn ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: No , sir ! At night she leaves there , only to reappear in the morning .

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: H 'm ! that would almost be sufficient reason —— George !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Uncle ?

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: I have changed my mind . You must accompany Marie !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Just as you say , uncle !

sp.speaker: Brauer
sp.p: And no quarreling this time , Marie !

sp.speaker: Marie
sp.p: Yes , papa .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: On the veranda .There , there , look ! The first bonfire ! !

div.stage: Singing and laughter is heard in distance . A red glow is seen .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: Have you taken care , Mr. Paul , to keep them far enough away from the sheds ?

sp.speaker: Paul
sp.p: Yes , Mrs. Brauer !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brauer
sp.p: For you must know . Pastor , last year the sparks came very near setting fire to the straw roofs .

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: There is a second one now , and there on the hill , another . See , George , see ! How beautiful !

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Yes , yes , darling , I see !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Pulls him forward softly .Why do you call me darling to-day ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Well , sha n't I ?

sp.speaker: Gertrude
sp.p: Oh , of course ; but do you love me more to-day ?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: I love you always , my pet !

sp.speaker: Gertrude
